natural problem: What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$.
natural solution: If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes average :: real
assumes h0 : "average = (\<Sum> i in {x. 1000 <= x \<and> x < 3000}. i) / card {x. 1000 <= x \<and> x < 3000} in base 3"
and h1 : "average = (\<Sum> i in {x. 10 <= x \<and> x < 100}. i) / card {x. 10 <= x \<and> x < 100} in base 6"
shows  "average in base 10 = 31"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes average :: real
assumes h0 : "average = (\<Sum> i in {x. 1000 <= x \<and> x < 3000}. i) / card {x. 1000 <= x \<and> x < 3000} in base 3"
and h1 : "average = (\<Sum> i in {x. 10 <= x \<and> x < 100}. i) / card {x. 10 <= x \<and> x < 100} in base 6"
shows  "average in base 10 = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Calculate the average of the numbers from 1000 to 2999 in base 3, and the average of the numbers from 10 to 99 in base 6. If both averages are equal, what is the value of this average in base 10? The final answer is 31.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes avg :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<longrightarrow> (n div 10 + n mod 10) div 2 = avg n"
shows  "avg 1111 = 31"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes avg :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<longrightarrow> (n div 10 + n mod 10) div 2 = avg n"
shows  "avg 1111 = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Define a function $avg(n)$ as the average of the sum of the last digit of $n$ and the first digit of $n$ for any integer $n$ between 1000 and 2222. What is $avg(1111)$? The final answer is 31.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1000..2222} \<and> n \<in> {10..55}"
shows  "average n = 31"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<in> {1000..2222} \<and> n \<in> {10..55}"
shows  "average n = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the average of a natural number $n$ that lies in both the set of natural numbers from 1000 to 2222 and the set of natural numbers from 10 to 55. The final answer is 31.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<longrightarrow> (int (n div 1000) * (3^3)) + (int (n div 100 mod 10) * (3^2)) + (int (n div 10 mod 10) * 3) + (int (n mod 10)) < 6^2"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<longrightarrow> (int (n div 1000) * (3^3)) + (int (n div 100 mod 10) * (3^2)) + (int (n div 10 mod 10) * 3) + (int (n mod 10)) \<ge> 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> n. (int (n div 1000) * (3^3)) + (int (n div 100 mod 10) * (3^2)) + (int (n div 10 mod 10) * 3) + (int (n mod 10))) {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222} / int (card {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222}) = 31"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<longrightarrow> (int (n div 1000) * (3^3)) + (int (n div 100 mod 10) * (3^2)) + (int (n div 10 mod 10) * 3) + (int (n mod 10)) < 6^2"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<longrightarrow> (int (n div 1000) * (3^3)) + (int (n div 100 mod 10) * (3^2)) + (int (n div 10 mod 10) * 3) + (int (n mod 10)) \<ge> 6"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> n. (int (n div 1000) * (3^3)) + (int (n div 100 mod 10) * (3^2)) + (int (n div 10 mod 10) * 3) + (int (n mod 10))) {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222} / int (card {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2222}) = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Consider all the four-digit numbers from 1000 to 2222. For each number, compute a score by replacing each digit $d$ in the number from left to right with $d * 3^3$, $d * 3^2$, $d * 3^1$, and $d * 3^0$ respectively and add them up. If every number's score lies between $6$ and $6^2$, find the average score of all these numbers. The final answer is $31$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum> n \<in> {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n < 10000 \<and> int_to_base_3 n < 100 \<and> int_to_base_6 n < 10}. n) / card {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n < 10000 \<and> int_to_base_3 n < 100 \<and> int_to_base_6 n < 10}"
shows  "avg = 31"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum> n \<in> {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n < 10000 \<and> int_to_base_3 n < 100 \<and> int_to_base_6 n < 10}. n) / card {n. 1000 \<le> n \<and> n < 10000 \<and> int_to_base_3 n < 100 \<and> int_to_base_6 n < 10}"
shows  "avg = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the average of all numbers between 1000 and 10000 that, when converted to base 3, are less than 100 and when converted to base 6 are less than 10. The final answer is 31.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 81 \<and> n \<le> 242 \<longrightarrow> length (digits 3 n) = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 36 \<and> n \<le> 35 \<longrightarrow> length (digits 6 n) = 2"
shows  "(sum id {n. n \<ge> 81 \<and> n \<le> 242 \<and> length (digits 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (digits 6 n) = 2}) div card {n. n \<ge> 81 \<and> n \<le> 242 \<and> length (digits 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (digits 6 n) = 2} = 31"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: "nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 81 \<and> n \<le> 242 \<longrightarrow> length (digits 3 n) = 4"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 36 \<and> n \<le> 35 \<longrightarrow> length (digits 6 n) = 2"
shows  "(sum id {n. n \<ge> 81 \<and> n \<le> 242 \<and> length (digits 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (digits 6 n) = 2}) div card {n. n \<ge> 81 \<and> n \<le> 242 \<and> length (digits 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (digits 6 n) = 2} = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the average (integer division) of all natural numbers between 81 and 242 inclusive that have exactly 4 digits in base 3 and 2 digits in base 6. The final answer is 31.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes average :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<and> (\<forall>b. b = 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>k. k \<ge> 10 \<and> k \<le> 55 \<and> n = b * k))"
shows  "average = 31"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes average :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1000 \<and> n \<le> 2222 \<and> (\<forall>b. b = 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>k. k \<ge> 10 \<and> k \<le> 55 \<and> n = b * k))"
shows  "average = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the average value of the numbers between 1000 and 2222 inclusive that are multiples of 6 and can be represented as 6 times a number between 10 and 55. The final answer is 31.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum>n\<in>{n. n \<in> {1000..2222} \<inter> {10..55}}. n) / card ({n. n \<in> {1000..2222} \<inter> {10..55}})"
shows  "avg = 31"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum>n\<in>{n. n \<in> {1000..2222} \<inter> {10..55}}. n) / card ({n. n \<in> {1000..2222} \<inter> {10..55}})"
shows  "avg = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Calculate the average of the set of numbers that fall within both the range of 1000 to 2222 and 10 to 55. The final answer is 31.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum>x\<in>{n. n \<in> {1000..9999} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 3^k} \<inter> {n. n \<in> {10..99} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 6^k}}. real_of_int x) / card {n. n \<in> {1000..9999} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 3^k} \<inter> {n. n \<in> {10..99} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 6^k}"
shows  "avg = 31"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes avg :: real
assumes h0 : "avg = (\<Sum>x\<in>{n. n \<in> {1000..9999} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 3^k} \<inter> {n. n \<in> {10..99} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 6^k}}. real_of_int x) / card {n. n \<in> {1000..9999} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 3^k} \<inter> {n. n \<in> {10..99} \<and> \<exists>k. n = 6^k}"
shows  "avg = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the average of the set of numbers between 1000 and 9999, inclusive, that are powers of 3 and between 10 and 99, inclusive, that are powers of 6. The final answer is 31.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes average :: "int list \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. (length (to_base 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (to_base 6 n) = 2) \<longrightarrow> n \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "average = (\<Sum> n \<in> {n. length (to_base 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (to_base 6 n) = 2}. n) div size {n. length (to_base 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (to_base 6 n) = 2}"
shows  "average = 31"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the average of all positive integers that have four digits when written in base $3$, but two digits when written in base $6$? Write your answer in base $10$. The final Answer is 31
 ### Proof
 If an integer $n$ has four digits in base $3$, then $3^3\le n<3^4$. If an integer $n$ has two digits in base $6$, then $6^1\le n<6^2$. The overlap of these intervals is $$\{27,28,29,30,31,32,33,34,35\}.$$The average of the integers in this set is $\frac{27+35}{2} = \boxed{31}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes average :: "int list \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. (length (to_base 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (to_base 6 n) = 2) \<longrightarrow> n \<ge> 0"
and h1 : "average = (\<Sum> n \<in> {n. length (to_base 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (to_base 6 n) = 2}. n) div size {n. length (to_base 3 n) = 4 \<and> length (to_base 6 n) = 2}"
shows  "average = 31"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the average value of all positive integers that have exactly 4 digits when written in base 3 and exactly 2 digits when written in base 6. The final answer is 31.
